title: [Feature]: Enhance the About Us page UI by improving image-text alignment, layout balance, and overall visual appeal.
body:
# 🚀 Feature Request 

### 📝 Feature Description 
Enhance the About Us page UI by improving image-text alignment, layout balance, and overall visual appeal.

### 🔧 How Will This Enhance the App? 
These improvements will significantly enhance user experience by:
- Ensuring accurate representation of course content
- Improving readability and navigation
- Making the page more visually appealing and engaging
- Guiding users towards key actions

### 🎯 Use Cases 
- Users can quickly understand and navigate course offerings
- Increased engagement with the "Get Started" CTA
- Better comprehension of platform features through visual cues

### 📦 Suggested Implementation 
1. Image-Text Alignment: Match gallery images with their correct course descriptions.
2. Layout Balance: Implement a grid layout for course cards to reduce clutter.
3. Call-to-Action: Add a prominent "Get Started" button in a strategic location.
4. Whitespace: Increase padding and margins around elements.
5. Icons: Introduce relevant icons next to course categories and key features.

### 📸 Additional Context 
Currently, the About Us page has mismatched images and descriptions, creating confusion. The layout feels cluttered, making it difficult for users to focus on individual offerings. By addressing these issues and implementing the suggested improvements, we can create a more intuitive and visually appealing user interface that better represents our platform's quality and professionalism.

assign this issue to @ananas304 with appropriate tags suck as gssoc, gssoc-ext, hacktoberfest.

Thankyou for your time:)

title: Enhance_Real_Time_Password_Validation_in_Signup_Form!
body:
**Criteria**:

- At least 8 characters long
- At least 1 uppercase letter (A-Z)
- At least 1 lowercase letter (a-z)
- At least 1 number (0-9)
- At least 1 special character (e.g., !@#$%^&*())

**Real-Time Validation:**
The validation checks are performed on input to provide immediate feedback on password strength.
Each criterion is validated and indicated individually, allowing users to see which requirements are still unmet.

title: [feat] : Improve login.js features for faster loading times and readability
body:
Hi @Vin205 !! I saw your code and all major changes have been taken care of. I just want to suggest some changes in the login.js file to:- 

1. **Separation of Concerns** : The Login.js file is broken down into smaller sub-components (LoginHeader, LoginForm, LoginFooter) for 
    better readability and maintainability.
2. **Consistent Naming Conventions** : Consistent and descriptive naming conventions are used for state variables and functions.
3. **Code Efficiency** : The code is structured in a way that avoids unnecessary re-renders and optimizes state updates.
4. **Error Handling** : Enhanced error handling is included to provide more detailed feedback to users.
5. **User Experience** : The loading state and accessibility are considered to improve the user experience.

This requires many changes but it enhances the overall quality of the code and readability of code.Please assign me this issue.

Thanks,
Yash Vashishth
(Contributor, GSSoC'24(Ext) and Hacktoberfest)

title: Title: Add Pre-commit Hook to Run Prettier and ESLint
body:
I’d like to propose adding a pre-commit hook to our backend application. This hook would run both **Prettier** and **ESLint** before any commits are made. Here’s why I think this is a great idea:

- **Consistency**: By automatically formatting code with Prettier and checking for linting issues with ESLint, we can ensure that our code remains consistent across the team.
  
- **Efficiency**: This setup can help catch formatting and linting issues before they make it into the codebase, reducing the time spent during code reviews.

- **Simplicity**: Having these tools run automatically means developers won’t have to remember to run them manually. It streamlines our workflow!

Implementing this change could greatly enhance our development process and maintain code quality.

title: Implement User Login and Signup Routes with JWT Authentication in Backend
body:
**Objective:**  
We need to set up the backend routes for user login and signup using JSON Web Tokens (JWT) for authentication.

**What We Need to Do:**

1. **User Signup Route:**
   - Create a route that allows users to register.
   - Validate the user input (like checking email format and password strength).
   - Make sure to hash passwords before saving them to the database.
   - Return a JWT when the signup is successful.

2. **User Login Route:**
   - Set up a route for users to log in.
   - Validate the user credentials (like checking the email and password).
   - Upon successful login, return a JWT that users can use for authenticated requests later on.

**A Few Things to Keep in Mind:**
- Handle error responses nicely (for example, if a user already exists or if the credentials are invalid).
- Think about using middleware to verify JWTs on any protected routes.

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- The routes should work correctly and provide appropriate responses.
- The JWT should be generated and verified properly.
- Please include tests to ensure that the login and signup functionality is working as expected.

Please assign me to this task.
author: tejasbenibagde

comments.body: @tejasbenibagde assigned!
Ok Thank you but before starting into this can you tell me how should a user schema look like? like what fields I should add to the user model ?

title: add contributing.md file

title: Secure Firebase keys, fix duplicate navbar issue, and prepare for authentication
body:
### Summary
Before starting work on **fix #74**, I identified a critical security issue where the Firebase configuration keys were publicly exposed. To address this, I created a `.env` file and added a `.env.sample` file containing the structure for the Firebase configuration. 🔒

Here’s the content of the `.env.sample` file:

``` bash
REACT_APP_FIREBASE_API_KEY=
REACT_APP_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN=
REACT_APP_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID=
REACT_APP_FIREBASE_STORAGE_BUCKET=
REACT_APP_FIREBASE_MESSAGING_SENDER_ID=
REACT_APP_FIREBASE_APP_ID=
```

### Other Fixes
Additionally, I resolved a duplicate navbar error and fixed import spacing issues.

### Next Steps
I will now proceed with implementing authentication using Firebase.

### Maintainer Note
@skmirajulislam  It’s imperative to keep Firebase keys private to prevent unauthorized access to the database and other sensitive data. This issue must be treated with the utmost seriousness to safeguard the project. 🚨

Also please add `hacktoberfest`, `gssoc-ext` and `level 2` label
author: VaibhavKatariya

comments.body:
Thank you for your PR. However, I won’t be able to award you 2 points for this submission as the navbar issue has already been resolved by Devanshu, who has received the reward for it. The change you've made is relatively minor, so I can award you 1 point for this.

Additionally, I would like to remind you not to create multiple issues and PRs for a single task. I’ve already listed the complete implementation, and once that is done, you’ll receive the full 3 points at once.

Thank you for your feedback! I understand the point about not creating multiple issues or PRs for a single task. However, since the exposure of the Firebase configuration keys was a serious security issue, I felt it was necessary to create a PR to address that.
@VaibhavKatariya this issue is reviewed by @Vin205 our Project Admin, wait till evolution!

@skmirajulislam, Since it's taking too long to review, could you please add `hacktoberfest`, `hacktoberfest-accepted` and `gssoc-ext` labels in the meantime?

Thanks!

@skmirajulislam Why has this been marked as invalid? It was a security concern, which is why I made the changes. At the very least, it should not have been marked as invalid since it's not a spam. I'm honestly quite disappointed.
@VaibhavKatariya i already told you dont raise multiple PR for same, in your recent PR update tracked thats why!

title: Added a profile card Component
body:
This pull request introduces a new ProfileCard component for the user dashboard. The ProfileCard displays the user's name, role, and includes a button to edit profile information.

Key Changes

- Created a new ProfileCard.js component under the components/Common directory.
- Integrated the ProfileCard into the Server.js
- Added state management to handle the "Edit Profile" button.
- Created a ProfileForm.js component to allow users to update their profile information.

How to Test

- Navigate to the dashboard.
- Verify that the ProfileCard displays user details.
- Click the "Edit Profile" button to see the profile editing form.
- Update the name field and save changes.
author: priyanshi-codes

please provide your issue number!

title: Suggestion: Transition to Next.js for Enhanced Performance and Firebase Integration
body:
Hi Team,

I noticed the project is currently using separate frontend and backend folders, with React for the frontend. I’d like to suggest switching to **Next.js**, as it allows for building both the frontend and backend in a unified framework. Here's why Next.js could be a better fit:

1. **Fullstack Capabilities**: With Next.js, you can handle both frontend and backend logic, as it includes built-in API routes. This eliminates the need to maintain separate folders for the frontend and backend, streamlining development.

2. **Server-Side Rendering (SSR) & Static Generation**: Next.js supports SSR and static generation out of the box. This can drastically improve performance and SEO, especially beneficial for content-heavy or dynamic pages.

3. **Automatic Code Splitting**: Next.js automatically splits the code, making sure only necessary components are loaded initially, improving page load times.

4. **Improved Developer Experience**: The framework includes features like file-based routing and seamless TypeScript support, making development faster and more efficient.

I also noticed that the Firebase label is added but not yet used. Next.js integrates smoothly with Firebase for features like authentication, database, and hosting, making it easy to manage backend services within the same project.

Let me know your thoughts on this suggestion. I'd be happy to help with the migration if you decide to move forward with Next.js. Additionally, it would be great if you could add labels for **Hacktoberfest** and **GSSoC Level 3** to this issue.
author: VaibhavKatariya

comments.body:
Hi @skmirajulislam ,

Thank you for the clarification! I understand the importance of keeping the project within the planned tech stack and the challenges a migration might introduce, especially considering Hacktoberfest and GSSoC rules.

I’d still love to contribute with React.js and will look for opportunities where I can assist. Please feel free to assign me any React-related tasks or issues that need attention!

Looking forward to keep contributing!

Best regards,  
@VaibhavKatariya

@VaibhavKatariya 

you can implement our backed, till now its empty for this ill give you label 3 under GSSOC & hactoberfest, if you able to implement it without any internal conflict, feel free to ask me!

@skmirajulislam,

I'm definitely interested in developing the backend, especially since I have hands-on experience with Firebase.

Could you provide a brief overview of what the backend should look like and what technologies we will be using? That would be highly appreciated!

Looking forward to your guidance!

title: [DOC]: Add Basic Snapshotting(git status, git commit) , branching and merging commands
body:
### Issue Description
The existing Readme.md file contains commands for cloning the projects to the users' local system. I would like to contribute by adding commands for branching, committing changes as well as push the changes in proper format.

### Suggested Change
I would like to contribute by adding following commands:

**Basic Snapshotting**

-git status
-git add [file-name.txt]
-git commit -m "[commit message]"
-Branching and Merging

-git checkout -b [branch name]
-git push -u origin [branch name]
-git pull upstream main
-git remote -v
-git remote add upstream

### Rationale
Contributors, especially the ones new to open source contributions will find it easier to contribute and thus it would play a role in ensuring easy workflow.

Please assign me this issue under ggsoc'24 extd and hacktoberfest.
author: Devaki01

Description:
A Code of Conduct document needs to be added to the Enyanjyoti website's repository to outline the expected behavior and guidelines for contributors. This document will help ensure a positive, inclusive, and respectful environment for all community members.

Expected Outcome:
The CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md file should be available in the repository, and contributors should be informed about the standards and practices for contributing to the project.

Purpose:
To ensure a safe, welcoming, and professional environment for all contributors and users of  Enyanjyoti

4. **Testimonials**: User reviews or success stories to build trust.
